articles.headline: At Chrysler, Home Depot Still Lingers
articles.snippet: Robert L. Nardelli, Chrysler’s new chief who earlier ran Home Depot, spoke about the auto industry in terms that suggested he was still in a home-improvement state of mind.
articles.abstract: Robert L. Nardelli, Chrysler’s new chief who earlier ran Home Depot, spoke about the auto industry in terms that suggested he was still in a home-improvement state of mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Oct. 29 — Robert L. Nardelli, the new Chrysler chief executive, has tried hard to sound like a “car guy” from the moment he landed in Detroit. He boasted at his first news conference, in August, about his well-stocked garage that included a Jeep, a Plymouth Prowler and a PT Cruiser.

articles.headline: Foreign Fighters of Harsher Bent Bolster Taliban
articles.snippet: The growing numbers of foreign fighters in Afghanistan are more violent and extreme than their local allies.
articles.abstract: The growing numbers of foreign fighters in Afghanistan are more violent and extreme than their local allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: GARDEZ, Afghanistan — Afghan police officers working a highway checkpoint near here noticed something odd recently about a passenger in a red pickup truck. Though covered head to toe in a burqa, the traditional veil worn by Afghan women, she was unusually tall. When the police asked her questions, she refused to answer.

articles.headline: Obama’s Account of New York Years Often Differs From What Others Say
articles.snippet: Some say that Barack Obama has taken some literary license in portraying the time he spent in Manhattan.
articles.abstract: Some say that Barack Obama has taken some literary license in portraying the time he spent in Manhattan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama does not say much about his years in New York City. The time he spent as an undergraduate at Columbia College and then working in Manhattan in the early 1980s surfaces only fleetingly in his memoir. In the book, he casts himself as a solitary wanderer in the metropolis, the outsider searching for a way to “make myself of some use.”

articles.headline: Bigger Budget? No, Responds Safety Agency
articles.snippet: The top consumer product safety official asked Congress to reject legislation that would strengthen the agency.
articles.abstract: The top consumer product safety official asked Congress to reject legislation that would strengthen the agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 — The nation’s top official for consumer product safety has asked Congress in recent days to reject legislation intended to strengthen the agency, which polices thousands of consumer goods, from toys to tools.

articles.headline: A Search for a Chief Who Can Unite Merrill Lynch
articles.snippet: Whoever is chosen will have to run both a thriving wealth management operation and a beaten-down bond business.
articles.abstract: Whoever is chosen will have to run both a thriving wealth management operation and a beaten-down bond business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Call it a tale of two investment banks. Whoever takes over as chief executive of Merrill Lynch will assume control of what is essentially two companies: a thriving wealth management operation growing at 70 percent a year and a beaten-down bond business that could end the year with over $10 billion in credit losses.

articles.headline: 774 Arrests in China Over Safety
articles.snippet: Regulators hailed the arrests, made during a  nationwide crackdown on tainted food, drugs and agricultural products, as a major step forward for consumer safety.
articles.abstract: Regulators hailed the arrests, made during a  nationwide crackdown on tainted food, drugs and agricultural products, as a major step forward for consumer safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, Oct. 29 —The Chinese government revealed today that it had arrested 774 people over the last two months as part of a nationwide crackdown on the production and sale of tainted food, drugs and agricultural products.

articles.headline: Gay Enclaves Face Prospect of Being Passé
articles.snippet: In the face of gentrification, a waning sense of belonging is being felt in gay neighborhoods across the country.
articles.abstract: In the face of gentrification, a waning sense of belonging is being felt in gay neighborhoods across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 — This Halloween, the Glindas, gladiators and harem boys of the Castro — along with untold numbers who plan to dress up as Senator Larry E. Craig, this year’s camp celebrity — will be celebrating behind closed doors. The city’s most popular Halloween party, in America’s largest gay neighborhood, is canceled.

articles.headline: Participants Left Uninformed in Some Halted Medical Trials
articles.snippet: Drug and medical device makers will not be forced to disclose the results of clinical trials on some products that never reached the marketplace.
articles.abstract: Drug and medical device makers will not be forced to disclose the results of clinical trials on some products that never reached the marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Congress passed a bill last month requiring makers of drugs and medical devices to disclose the results of clinical trials for all approved products, advocates of greater study disclosure applauded the move.

articles.headline: The Road to a South African Driver’s License
articles.snippet: To secure a driver’s license, South Africans must navigate a bureaucratic process so daunting that it has set off riots.
articles.abstract: To secure a driver’s license, South Africans must navigate a bureaucratic process so daunting that it has set off riots.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 29 — “You will never drive this way again in your life,” Cullen says.
